Award.AwardTitle: Identifying and Utilizing Upper Bounds for Diffusion-based Separations using Metal Organic Frameworks

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: 1604375, PI: Sholl, David
Title: Identifying and Utilizing Upper Bounds for Diffusion-based Separations using Metal Organic Frameworks

Bulk chemical separations are vital to the world-wide chemicals and fuels industries. Because these separations are largely performed with thermally-driven methods (e.g. distillation), they consume vast amounts of energy. Membrane-based separations offer a powerful alternative to conventional separations for a range of large-volume chemical separations. Commercial gas separations applications of membranes are dominated by polymeric membranes, but these membranes are limited by a fundamental trade-off between selectivity and throughput. Considerable progress has been made in recent years in making membranes from porous materials including metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The crystalline nature of MOFs means that the fundamental tradeoff that exists for polymeric membranes can in principle be overcome. It seems likely, however, that other physical phenomena will place bounds on the ultimate performance that is possible with MOF membranes. This project will use a combination of atomically-detailed modeling and experiments to establish upper bounds on the performance of MOFs as membranes for gas separations. This work will be critical in guiding the development of these membranes for key industrial applications.

The project will focus on small pore MOFs such as zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and hybrid ZIFs in which separations can be achieved by both adsorption and diffusion selectivity. The work will build upon recent work by the PIs that demonstrates the ability to predict molecular diffusivities in materials of this kind using molecular simulations. These calculations rely on free energy sampling techniques, since the diffusion of species that is of practical interest occurs far too slowly for direct molecular dynamics simulations to be used. It is also vital that the models accounting for all degrees of freedom in the adsorbent framework be used to accurately describe slowly diffusing species. Detailed molecular simulations will be performed for a series of small pore MOFs that have been selected to explore hypotheses about the existence of upper bound relationships for molecular diffusion in MOFs. Simulations will be tested and validated using direct experimental measurements of diffusion in selected materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored in detail the impact of structural and dynamical flexibility of nanoporous materials in describing molecular diffusion through their porous structures. We used ZIFs, a widely known class of nanoporous materials, as the basis for our study. This work provided strong evidence that molecular simulations of fully flexible ZIFs can be used to make reliable predictions about molecular diffusivities. Furthermore, we provided insight on structure-diffusion relationships in mixed-linker ZIFs, in which two (or more) chemically distinct organic linkers are combined with a set of metal centers. We used a combination of 2D NMR and modeling to directly assess this local ordering in mixed-linker ZIFs for the first time and used lattice-gas modeling to qualitatively probe the effects of local ordering and linker composition on molecular diffusion in these materials. Our interest in mixed-linker ZIFs led us to develop a reliable molecular force-field (FF) for several ZIF families. In addition to our work on mixed-linker ZIFs, our new FF allowed us to carefully study the role of pore shape and functionality on diffusion of chemically diverse set of 30 molecules. Our results indicate that any attempt to accurately describe molecular diffusion in nanoporous materials must incorporate degrees of freedom associated with the adsorbent material. This is a powerful example of the observation that kinetic separations are likely to have a wider “dynamic range” than equilibrium based separations in terms of the selectivities that are physically possible. Overall, our work provided careful experimental characterization of mixed-linker ZIFs and also developed detailed models predicting molecular diffusion in these materials as a function of linker composition. Detailed molecular simulation methods were used to predict molecular diffusivities for a set of 30 molecules in a set of isostructural ZIFs with varying linkers. This set of calculations provides the most diverse characterization of molecular diffusion in small pore MOFs to date. We disseminated our results in seven papers to date. Three PhD students received partial support from this award. Upon graduation, these students were readily absorbed into US industry and are working in the areas of nanoporous materials, semiconductor materials, and data analytics. The PI and co-PI have given multiple seminars and invited talks in academia, industry and at technical conferences to disseminate the outcomes of this project.
